results.title: Comedies. 1st 20 years. Part 1: 1903-1904
results.brief_description:
Compilation of silent comedy motion pictures restored from the Library of Congress paper prints.
Contents: The Dude and the burglars (1903)—The Story of the Biograph told (1904)—Personal (1904)—The Widow and the only man (1904)—The Lost child (1904)

results.title: Comedian harmonists
results.creator_credit: Perathon, Iduna, Bavaria Film, Senator and Joseph Vilsmaier
results.brief_description: A dramatised account of the legendary German singing group ‘Comedian Harmonists’. Consisting of five singers and a pianist this close harmony group combined smooth melodies and comedy routines, performing jazz songs and German favorites in their own idiosyncratic style. They sang in several languages and starred in more than a dozen films. Vilsmaier tells the story of the groups rise to fame, their international success in the late twenties and early thirties, and their demise in 1934 when the Nazis branded their music as ‘degraded’ and prohibited it- three of the six musicians were Jewish. Essentially an affectionate tribute to the group, the film adopts the style of the traditional musical biopic. As with his earlier films ‘Herbstmilch’, ‘Rama Dama’ and ‘Stalingrad’, in this film Vilsmaier once again focuses on Germany in the 1930’s effectively portraying the treatment of Jewish artists during the National Socialism-Era. Cast includes Ben Becker, Heino Ferch, Ulrich Noethen, Heinrich Schafmeister, Kai Wiesinger, Katja Riemann, Meret Becker and Otto Sander. In German with English subtitles.

results.title: Come to Daddy
results.brief_description: Chris Cunningham’s infamous film clip for electronic artist Aphex Twins is a terrifying trip into the dark side. The clip begins ominously enough with a young girl skipping down a grotty laneway. When an old lady comes across the child, the little girl reveals a creepy mutated face, which bears a disturbing resemblance to Aphex Twin Richard D. James. As the music begins to freak out, with the refrain ‘I want your soul’ being chanted through the distortion, the helpless old lady ultimately finds herself face to face with sheer horror.

results.title: Come September
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture and Robert Rothols
results.brief_description: This film was made during the Centenary Royal Show in 1972, to commemorate 100 years of traditional partnership between the Department of Agriculture and the Royal Agriculture Society in the Royal Show. Using locations sound and music only, the film aims to give an impression of the contrasting facets of the Melbourne Show, and how it sets out to attract a wide range of people, mainly from urban areas.

results.title: Come see the dolphins
results.creator_credit: Coronet Instructional Media and Tom Ascher
results.brief_description: Presents the story of a young boy who accompanies his father, a dolphin keeper, to the zoo to see the dolphins. The boy learns of the appearance of dolphins, what they eat and how they communicate and navigate. Skillful photography includes observations underwater and behind the scenes views of equipment and workers needed to maintain the dolphin pool.

results.title: Come out fighting
results.brief_description: A young Aboriginal boxer is taken up by University students and finds it hard to adjust entering their bourgeois white world. This short is ragged and rough around the edges but it offers a rivetting glimpse into black and white relations in the early seventies, as well as some wonderful realistic sequences set in inner-city boxing gyms.

results.title: Come out fighting
results.brief_description: Low budget realistic work made with assistance from the Experimental Film and Television Fund. Adapted from a play by Harry Martin, it presents a crisis in the life of an Aboriginal boxer in the face of conflicting demands from Aboriginal friends, fight promoters and students campaigning for Aboriginal rights. Cast includes Michael Karpaney, Cliff Neale, Bethany Lee, Peter Green, Bob Horsfall, Peter Adams, Brian Torrens.
